qas.question: Where did Joseph Swan demonstrate his lamp in January 1879?

answers.text: at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemical Society

qas.question: Which vacuum pump expert helped Swan invent his lamp?
Why was Swan's first lamp not commercially viable?
When did Swan receive a patent for parchmentised thread?
What was the first public building to install electric lighting?

answers.text: the Savoy Theatre in the City of Westminster, London

qas.question: Who did not help Swan in 1878?

plausible_answers.text: processing that avoided the early bulb blackening

qas.question: What method did Swan not develop in 1878?

plausible_answers.text: a lamp using a slender carbon rod

qas.question: What was not shown at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemistry Society?

plausible_answers.text: a lamp using a slender carbon rod

qas.question: What was shown to an audience of 800 who attended a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle?
Why was Swan's first lamp commercially viable?

context: With the help of <a1_0><b5_0>Charles Stearn<b5_0/><a1_0/>, an expert on vacuum pumps, in 1878, Swan developed a method of <b6_0>processing that avoided the early bulb blackening<b6_0/>. This received a British Patent in 1880.[dubious – discuss] On 18 December 1878, <b7_0><b8_0>a lamp using a slender carbon rod<b8_0/><b7_0/> was shown <a0_0>at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemical Society<a0_0/>, and Swan gave a working demonstration at their meeting on 17 January 1879. It was also shown to 700 who attended a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on 3 February 1879. These lamps used a carbon rod from an arc lamp rather than a slender filament. Thus they had low resistance and required very large conductors to supply the necessary current, so they were not commercially practical, although they did furnish a demonstration of the possibilities of incandescent lighting with relatively high vacuum, a carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires. Besides requiring too much current for a central station electric system to be practical, they had a very short lifetime. Swan turned his attention to producing a better carbon filament and the means of attaching its ends. He devised a method of treating cotton to produce <a2_0><b9_0>'parchmentised thread'<b9_0/><a2_0/> and obtained British Patent 4933 in <a3_0>1880<a3_0/>. From this year he began installing light bulbs in homes and landmarks in England. His house was the first in the world to be lit by a lightbulb and also the first house in the world to be lit by hydroelectric power. In 1878 the home of Lord Armstrong at Cragside was also among the first houses to be lit by electricity. In the early 1880s he had started his company. In 1881, <a4_0>the Savoy Theatre in the City of Westminster, London<a4_0/> was lit by Swan incandescent lightbulbs, which was the first theatre, and the first public building in the world, to be lit entirely by electricity.
